params.text:
Translating with an NMT system is not very exciting. After choosing a particular language combination, you usually have a text box in which you can write or paste a few words or sentences or maybe upload a document. After launching the translation, you will see your sentences processed and output by the NMT system. At this point you will just be able to see if the output is up to your expectations or not. Also if the format in your document at least renders well after being processed. Things get more interesting when the system you are translating with is your own system. You know which type of corpora it was trained and optimised with, the scores it produces, the type of text that it will be (and not be) able to cope with. Your expectations will be probably more according to all this work that you previously did. Let’s see if they are actually met and maybe go a bit inside the translation process. And, why not, let’s compare systems. Ready, steady, go!

 

We will use MutNMT to do this activity. On the Engines section, among the Public Engines or already on Your Engines, you’ll find several systems that share the same language. Grab three of them. First of all, take a look at their training logs using the three dot menu next to each engine. For each engine, fill in the following information (you need to copy the table in a piece of paper):

Besides this, take a look at the corpora that you are not familiar with at the Data section to get the feeling of which kind of content they cover. This will be useful to better refine the domain set for the engines.

Let’s take a sentence like “This is a very important day for human rights”. First of all, go to Translate and copy and paste this sentence into the text bot. Now open the engines menu and choose one of the three in your previous selection. See how the sentence gets translated and write them down (please, copy the table in a piece of paper first):
Engine name Translation for: "This is an important day for human rights"

params.taskDescription: Not much fun, right? Let’s now see a bit which options did the engine manage besides the one at the output. We will do it by going to Inspect section. Take the very same sentence (probably offered as default) and inspect it using the different MT engines that you previously selected. Let’s concentrate on the list of candidate translations managed by the system, the n-best list. Which are the main issues of the candidate translations in this list (name at least 2)?
params.placeholderText: Some possible questions to be answered: Do you see any truncated translations? Do you see agreement issues in the translations? Do you see the variety of translations for “human rights”?

params.text: We are going to try with a slightly different sentence like “This is an awesome season for family picnics.” Let’s compare translations delivered by the different engines in the Compare section. Write them down ((please, copy the table in a piece of paper first):
Engine name Translation for: "This is an awesome season for family picnics."

Are the resulting translations problematic? Are these translations more problematic than the ones for the previous sentence? Why do you think that this happened? 

 

Take these sentences and inspect them using the Inspect feature on MutNMT. You’ll probably see a very different n-best list, with candidate translations struggling to output an actual translation. Could you summarize the main issues that you observe in the n-best lists again?
params.placeholderText: Probably none of the systems will know vocabulary like "awesome" or "picnics":   Do you see any <unk> symbols? Do you know what it means? Do you see any untranslated words? Do you see any “invented” words?

params.text: Data used to train an engine means all to this engine. Usually generic engines will be able to cope with a much more heterogeneous type of content and custom will do a particularly good job with content on the domain of the data they were trained with. Translating with an MT is fun after all, don’t you think so?
